The concept is clearly very silly but thankfully it provides plenty of good laughs as it spoofs the genre without going too far. Jennifer Love Hewitt is solid in the more 'straight guy' role of Del Blaine and Jason Isaacs is good as the real Devlin, even if his role is relatively small. The villains plot is clearly preposterous but it fits in with the silliness of the film; pity the villain wasn't a little more menacing thought. There isn't much to cause offence so this is probably suitable for younger viewers. Overall I enjoyed this; one has to be in the mood for silliness though.

review_title: Jackie Chan and Jennifer Love Hewitt keep "The Tuxedo" from coming apart at the seams.
review_detailed_main:
The first scene of "The Tuxedo" has a fawn standing in a stream. A nice, gentle opening... and then the creature urinates in the stream to usher in the opening credits. As Jennifer Love Hewitt's character says later on, "That passes for humour around here."

In fairness, the movie isn't quite as crude all the way through, but this action-comedy-spy caper really needs some alterations as far as its script (by the Michaels Leeson and J. Wilson) and direction (Kevin Donovan) are concerned - the story of NY cab driver Jackie Chan getting recruited as a superspy's chauffeur, acquiring his boss's specially engineered tuxedo when the man himself is incapacitated, and joining forces with equally amateurish but eager young spy Jennifer Love Hewitt to get to the bottom of a fellow agent's death could have been a treat if the writing had been better. And if there had been a director who knew how to handle action and comedy; Chan's breakneck drive through the streets of New York and a car/skateboard chase are particularly poorly done.

The movie does improve as it goes along, with Chan making you believe his character (who's hopeless at martial arts) really is being manipulated by the tux, especially in the "Pants Only" scene - this movie does give him more special effects help than any of his other ones, but given that the plot involves people dying of dehydration and a swarm of insects it's forgivable; plus while he's not as old as Charles Bronson (who was still doing action movies for Cannon in his 70s, let us not forget) he can be forgiven for wanting to lighten the load a bit. Jason Isaacs is entertaining as the real superspy, andas our hero's partner JLH is fun and as appealing as ever - she's come in for some flak in other comments here and elsewhere, but she does all right; I think we should all thank heaven we got her and not Chris Tucker again. (And not only because he's not as sexy as she is.)

None of Jackie Chan's Western movies have improved on his Asian ones (including "Rush Hour"), and this doesn't change things, but at least "The Tuxedo" (unlike "Shanghai Noon") isn't overlong, and it doesn't (unlike "Rush Hour 2") forget what it's supposed to be... it sets out to be an entertaining movie, and in the end that's what it is. Although that said, I can live happily without any more references to John Travolta in "Saturday Night Fever." (As opposed to any more gratuitous closeups of Jennifer Love Hewitt's body, but that's another matter.)

review_title: This is very very stupid, sad also
review_detailed_main:
Jackie Chan has reached a new low. I didn't thought he could do worse than Rush Hour 2, but he sure proved me wrong. This film is amongst the most lousy I have seen in my entire life!!.

It's even worse than his old american attempts (The Prospector and Battle Creek Brawl)... Hell it's even worse than some of Jet li stupid american movies. I simply don't understand how he could ever do this film.

I'm a big fan, and have seen all his Hong Kong movies (loved them all), but since he hit America it has just been one crappy film after another. He haven't made a good film since Accidental Spy - Now I'm just looking forward to the next chinese production; The Medallion.

Avoid this movie, and most likely the next 1000 american Jackie Chan films

PS. Sammo come back and save this guy (I just hope Gordon Chan can anyway)

Saw a screening of The Tuxedo yesterday (September 24, 2002).

Some movie stars create movie after movie. These movies become predictable, with the same style of repetitive action. If you'll excuse my language, "Same crap, different pile". However, I'm happy to say, that Tuxedo isn't one of these movies!

Tuxedo is a perfect blend of fresh action, adventure and humour! If a movie can make me literally laugh out loud, it's a good movie. But this one gets you going on several occasions. The action and adventure portion is non-stop and witty. For example, in one scene, Jimmy Tong is wearing his pants, but not the jacket. The pants spring to action, leading Jimmy to fight with only his legs. You've got to see it to appreciate it.

It definitely worth the price of admission! 4 1/2 out of 5!!

Since 1986 I have been watching (& watching!) Jackie Chan movies at every possible moment! I have collected every (I think) film he's made/appeared in since 1970. I love all of them. Some of them are pretty naff but I still find something to enjoy about them. Now, The Tuxedo, there were high expectations which unfortunately are not quite met. But it doesn't stop this film from being entertaining. Just leave the brain at home. JC has never really tried to make Oscar winning movies. He just wants to entertain. So stop panning this movie unless you have something genuine to say. JC is 49 years old this year (still fitter than this 31 year old writer!!), can you really expect him to be putting his body through the same punishment he was 10 or 20 years ago? No, is the simple answer, so what if there's a little camera trickery and CPU effects to enhance the film. JC's just out to make movies and entertain and Tuxedo does what it says on the tin! Lets face it, JC made films in the 70's which totally bombed at the box office, but are now considered classics. So all you negative critics may just be helping make this another classic!!!!!

review_title: There are a few good fight sequences and funny lines but not enough to make up for how cheesy this movie is.
review_detailed_main: The Tuxedo (2002) is a movie I watched again for the first time in a long time on HBOMAX. The storyline follows a cab driver who meets the right person at the right time who offers him a significant raise to become his personal driver. His new boss ends up being a secret agent who does dealings with the wrong people as part of his mission. The driver puts on a suit one day that causes him to have extravagant martial arts capabilities. When his boss goes missing he joins another agent to help track his boss down. This movie is directed by Kevin Donovan (What would Trejo Do) in his directorial debut and stars Jackie Chan (Rush Hour), Jennifer Love Hewitt (I Know What You Did Last Summer), Jason Isaacs (Harry Potter), Peter Stormare (Fargo), Romany Malco (40-Year Old Virgin) and Debi Mazar (Empire Records). The storyline for this picture is absolutely dreadful...so is the acting. Jennifer Love Hewitt was miserable to watch in this film. Almost every scene with her was awkward and painful. The martial arts scenes were also hit or miss. There are a few good fight sequences and funny lines but not enough to make up for how cheesy this movie is. Overall, I would recommend skipping this movie and would score it a 2/10.

As Jackie Chans number one fan... (aren't we all), I knew the move to Hollywood was going to put a dampener on the man we all know and love!

Rush Hour, as successful as it was, was a great vehicle for him, yet still managed to restrict the clown prince of kung fu who OWNED each of his films up to then.

With his Hollywood pictures, it feels as if Jackie is taking one step forward and one step back - never really being allowed to show the true star that he really is!

The Tuxedo, as one of his earlier US films, falls somewhere in between...

Although shot in Toronto, this film is dripping with pure Hollywood cheese that really rattles my cage, and some of its main stunts are cut and repeated so much it takes away from the work involved.

On that note, and knowing that it is the Tuxedo that makes Jackie fight (I know - ridiculous), he is still held back from some incredible 'what- could-have-been' moments, as he has that many wires strapped to him!

Personally, if it was my film, I would have put the amazing Sammo Hung in the role. Allowing such a suit to give his portly butt those moves would have been stronger and funnier.

That said, The Tuxedo does get viewed in our house often. The kids love it, and I haven't tired of seeing it yet... Enjoyable!

review_title: Not one of Jackie Chan's best
review_detailed_main:
Jackie Chan is fabulous, I think he's really funny, can do incredible stunts and is always entertaining but this film is not his best. It's not anything to do with him, just the other actors are a bit cheesy (not Jennifer Love-Hewitt, she's fine) and the story is pretty stupid. I guess it is a children's film, sort of, but it's got a little bit more adult humour than one expects from Jackie Chan, but I liked that.

The SFX aren't very good, the wire work is obvious, and whilst it is clearly a fantasy sci-fi it's just too silly to be sensible and I couldn't get involved or care anything for the characters or the disaster they were trying to avert.

Watch it, but don't expect too much.

review_title: Not Jackie Chan's best, but entertaining nevertheless
review_detailed_main:
Lots of fun, but you have to like Jackie Chan movies, which I do. Not too impressed with Jennifer Love Hewitt, whose character seems to waffle between being physically inept and being a martial arts expert---that could be the fault of the director, though. I'm also tired of the old, old cliche that putting a pair of glasses on a Barbie doll turns her into an unattractive braniac, so that has something to do with my annoyance with her as well. Taking those things into account, she probably did a perfectly fine job.

All in all, not quite as good as previous Jackie Chan movies, but an entertaining way to spend a couple of hours.

I saw this on netflix and I was like damn I didn't know Jackie Chan and Jenifer Love Hewitt did a movie together. Knew it would be cheesy af, was not disappointed.

It's worth it just for the part where a whole team of secret agents blocks off a busy city block and attacks innocent people just to give Jackie Chan a chance to hit on a Chinese girl he thinks is hot. I mean they literally have a guy repel from a building just to knock out a guy biking down the street, and they taze another guy that was gonna block Chan... and that guy is Colin Mockery from Whoes Line is it Anyway. Oh man, so funny... like not in they way they intended for it to be, but better. FYI I wouldn't call that a spolier because it's totally irralavent to the plot, but it shows how goofy this movie is.

Well, I went into the theaters with the excitement, because there was a new Jackie Chan movie. I left the theater somewhat puzzled, because I didn't see a Jackie Chan movie.

This is not a Jackie Chan movie in the traditional sense. Jackie Chan movies are the great ones such as Police Story, First Strike, The Drunken Master series and Rumble In The Bronx. The Tuxedo is an American 'action' comedy that just so happens to have Chan in it.

All the stunts were done with wires, and it is very apparent. There is maybe 5-10 minutes of fighting and even then stupid American directing ruins them. Too much editing and cutting, and the camera is too close, so much of the fighting is lost.

JLH did not belong in the movie; she just doesn't fit IN the movie. It was an extremely odd match up. Although she provides the movie's eye candy, I would rather have the good fights and stunts that the typical Jackie Chan movies are known for.

The story is somewhat weak, there was a weak buildup of what was supposed to be a real evil villain.

I left the theater disappointed because I saw a really bad action movie. Maybe Jackie will go make some Chinese movies again so there can be another good Jackie Chan movie. Not this poor substitute.

I can't stress this fact enough; this is not a Jackie Chan movie. This is an American 'Action' Comedy, which happens to star Jackie Chan. Little fighting, no true stunts, lots of wirework, and a poor story. I recommend just renting some of his better movies instead.

Taxi Driver Jimmy Tong (Jackie Chan) is given the job of chauffeur to smooth secret agent Clark Devlin (Jason Isaacs), but after a bomb blast almost kills Devlin, Jimmy enters the world of espionage posing as his boss. With the help of sexy scientist Del Blaine (Jennifer Love Hewitt) and the use of Devlin's top secret, gadget laden tuxedo, Jimmy tries to defeat Dietrich Banning, a maniac plotting to poison America's reservoirs.

I've been promising to show my 8-year-old son something from my kung fu collection for quite some time now, but due to the high level of violence in most of my martial arts DVDs, the majority were not really suitable; in the end, I gave him the choice between two Jackie Chan films: Twin Dragons or The Tuxedo. Unfortunately, he chose the latter, one of the Jackie's more recent films which I had avoided so far thanks to its being mainstream Hollywood fare aimed at a family audience. Still, I was willing to give it a go since it co-starred Jennifer Love Hewitt, whose looks and magnificent cleavage make even the lamest movies easier to endure.

As I expected, this film features very little in the way of decent action or story: the plot is awful, the comedy weak, the fight scenes far too reliant on special effects and wire work, and Peter Stormare and Debi Mazar are totally wasted in a throwaway roles. As I had suspected, curvacious Jennifer Love Hewitt is easily the breast thing... err, I mean the best thing about the whole rather sorry affair.

I rate The Tuxedo a miserable 2/10, plus a generous extra pair of points for JLH's extra-generous pair of points.

A hard luck cabbie, who just cannot seem to catch a break, named Jimmy Tong (Jackie Chan) is hired to be the limousine driver for top secret super CSA agent/spy extraordinaire Clark Devlin when he impresses another CSA agent named Steena (Debi Mazar) with his fast driving expertise. However, when Devlin winds up gravely injured following an explosion, he asks Jimmy to take over his assignment and tells him to wear his specially equipped tuxedo. This tuxedo as it turns out isn't ordinary in the least. In fact, it's a technological marvel capable of providing its user with whatever skill is desired, whether it be fighting, dancing or gun assembly, just by selecting it from a fancy wrist-watch also included in the outfit. Yes, Jimmy Tong finds himself suddenly thrust into a new world of excitement by assuming the Clark Devlin role. Eventually he is paired up with a new CSA agent out to prove her worth in Del Blaine (Jennifer Love-Hewitt). Together they are to bring down whatever corrupt scheme of world domination one Dietrich Banning (Ritchie Coaster), head of a bottled water empire, may be planning. Only can Jimmy find the confidence within himself to get the job done?

In many ways, this is something of a poor imitation of the Pink Panther films, only dumbed down even more to appeal to a mass audience with such an emphasis on not offending any sensibility, it likely won't appeal to many in reality. As was done with the Pink Panther films, director Donovan here tries to blend action with comedy with the emphasis being on the physical comedy itself. You would think given the involvement of Jackie Chan, it would be natural fit but this one only offers up disappointment. The fights are uninspired and forgettable with too much wire work. The attempts at humor either fall flat or are outright unfunny or they play things way too safe. Jennifer Love-Hewitt is terribly miscast as the heroine. Not only is she thoroughly unconvincing in her role but her character never comes across as anything but perpetually bitchy. This movie's best scenes actually involve Jackie Chan doing uncharacteristic stuff like dancing and performing on stage and his early cab and limousine driver scenes. The theme of self-confidence could have been used better but here is one of the film's better elements. Jason Issacs brief Bond-like Clark Devlin appearance also proves very entertaining and is much too short-lived. In the end, this just isn't the Jackie Chan or even Jennifer Love-Hewitt fans will want to see.

If you accept the ridiculous premise that this tuxedo could do all the things in the movie (eh why not, it's a fantasy movie), and an aggressive-driving nice-guy cab driver could be plucked off the street and hired to drive a superspy around without first getting extensive training and security clearance (umm, sure), and a pretty female lab rat suddenly becomes a seasoned superspy (this happens a lot in spy movies), then the rest of the movie makes sense.

Chan plays the same character he always plays, which is fine. His action sequences are fun to watch as always, although definitely not his best (see Rush Hour and of course Rumble in the Bronx). The villain is 2 dimensional and doesn't receive much screen time. Love-Hewitt shines in a comedic role, but I found her constant insubordination unbelievable and annoying. That was no fault of hers, she did a great job with the lines she got.

I really liked the tongue-in-cheek comment on bottled water in the title scene. Chan's send-up of James Brown was really well done, although the scene that followed where the pair tried to get information from the bad guys was pretty silly. Kinda ruined it.

Worth a few laughs. If you like Chan or spy movie spoofs, see it in a cheap theatre or rent it.

review_title: Even a Tuxedo Cannot Render Any Originality.
If you've got nothing better to do, this wouldn't be the worst thing to watch.
review_detailed_main:
As with all of Jackie's recent(ish) American films, wirework threatens to render this one unwatchable. Fortunately, Jackie is still charmingly adorable as the hapless Jimmy Tong and the gorgeous Jennifer Love Hewitt as Del Blaine can quite easily hold the attention of the straight male audience.

The dialogue is not too bad and JLH's performance is pretty good, especially her impersonation of the air headed bit player, Cheryl. Jackie's delivery of his own lines is what you'd expect in an English speaking film, but he was still funny. Of course, not as funny as his performance would have been had it been a cantonese speaking film in which his comedic style is, understandably, more natural.

Action-wise, this film is pretty much a dud and leaves the Jackie Chan fan with an urge to rewatch Project A or Armor of God for a dose of the good old days to wash away the sour taste of disappointment. Still, its not as bad as The Medallion.

And any film with Bob Balaban in it can't be entirely bad (I'm a big fan of his as well). To be honest though, its not a great film, but its not a terrible one either. It is saved somewhat just by Chan's presence and JLH's performance and some very nice dresses. Probably not worth paying money to see, but if its on tele and you've nothing better to do, its a decent time waster.

6/10

review_title: Looks impressive but the comedy is bad. 3/10
review_detailed_main:
Review: This is a big budget action/comedy movie with Jackie Chan playing a New York cab driver, Jimmy Tong, who gets an offer that he can't refuse! He's known for getting his clients to there destination with speed, so when a New York high flyer, Steena (Debi Mazar), jumps into his cab, she offers him double the fee if Jimmy can get her to her destination by the time she has finished putting on her make-up. After being thoroughly impressed with his driving, she offers him a job to be a chauffeur for millionaire, Clark Devin (Jason Isaacs), but he has to follow the many rules that Steena has given him. He soon builds a relationship with Clark but there car is targeted by henchmen, who want Clark dead. Jimmy tries his utmost to escape from a remote controlled car, which has a bomb attached to it but Clark gets severely injured in the explosion and ends up hospitalised. Clark gives Jimmy clues about who attempted to murder him but as he is unable to talk properly, Jimmy puts together the clues to try and find the murderer. When he gets back to his house, he goes through his possessions to try and piece the mystery together and he comes across a special Tuxedo, which is controlled by a wrist watch and can give the owner special powers. He then gets a call from a undercover, inexperienced field agent Del Blaine (Jennifer Love Hewitt), who wants to meet up with Clark to talk about a special mission. As she hasn't met Clark before, Jimmy poses as Clark in the special powered Tuxedo to try and take-down an international terrorist, Dietrich Banning (Ritchie Coaster), who plans to take over the world by putting chemicals in water. He then finds out that it was Dietrich who attempted to kill his boss so Jimmy has personal reasons to destroy Dietrich. After going undercover and worming there way into his operation, there cover is blown and they have to fight against Dietrich, who also gets his hands on a powerful Tuxedo. The action wasn't that great and the jokes aren't that funny. Chan makes a bit of a fool of himself by dancing, singing and making the Tuxedo take over his body and I wasn't that impressed with Jennifer Love Hewitt, who also wouldn't stop whining throughout the movie. On the plus side, you can tell that there was a big budget because it does look quite good and the concept was half decent but the comedy did get on my nerves after a while and it became more silly than funny. I did like Jason Isaacs, who would make a brilliant Bond and I found Ritchie Costner a convincing villain but the overall movie could do with a rewrite with some decent actors playing the leads. Disappointing!

Round-Up: This movie was directed by Kevin Donovan, who has only directed 4 shorts behind the camera. He was lucky to get the chance to work with Jackie Chan, with such a big budget but he failed to make a unique film that will stand the test of time. This movie did make its money back at the box office so it wasn't a total failure but I personally think that people were starting to get a bit fed up with Chan's style of comedy and they just wanted to see the action scenes more than the jokes. His brief Western encounter did bring out some decent movies, like the Rush Hour franchise but I much prefer his earlier, authentic movies which had some unbelievable stunts and epic action scenes.

Budget: $60million Worldwide Gross: $105million

I recommend this movie to people who are into their action/sci-fi/martial arts/comedies starring Jackie Chan, Jennifer Love Hewitt, Jason Isaacs, Debi Mazar, Ritchie Coaster, Peter Stormare and Romany Malco. 3/10

This is a great sketch for a film, but seems unpolished. After the incredible setup that centers around an amazing tuxedo with essentially nanotechnological elements, a first for mainstream cinema, it completely fails to be the really cool science fiction film it could have been. Instead, they made a movie that is run of the mill spy spoof fodder, with dialogue dumbed down and some flashes of Jackie Chan's kung fu genius, but he isn't allowed to really show his chops, and the fight scenes are almost hilariously short. Jennifer Love Hewitt is tolerable if a bit weirdly cast as an agent of the CSA, a parallel intelligence organization that also fails to be all that it could be. She is awfully cute, though even this aspect of her talent is wasted here, reduced to juvenile humor about peeping toms and groping. When a film like this is relying on the hot actress to buddy up with the kung fu legend and the hotness and kung fu are crippled, you get this movie. Probably a great rental if a bunch of people are watching.

I have been a fan of Jackie Chan for a while now and I have to wonder exactly why he made this film.

Jackie has always made entertaining movies with his blend of slapstick, physical movements and of course the martial arts that he performs so well (maybe second only to Jet Li). But this film has nothing to entertain.

The action is not well photographed and although the original fight scenes and action set pieces may have been well designed the photography and more importantly doesn't show them to the high standard we have come to expect from a Jackie Chan movie.

The only thing that I can see is the fact that Jackie must have been offered a fee that was impossible to say no to.

I wouldn't have said that this is a sell out movie but the more Hollywood movies Chan does the more it seems to dilute what has been so far a reasonably good career and cross over from Hong Kong to western mainstream.

Lets hope Jackie likes the movie as much as I did and never lowers himself to star in anything this bad again.

This was a movie I was waiting to see for over a year and I have to say this. My wait kindly rewarded with a spectacular action-comedy picture that as classy as the tuxedo itself. I liked that the actual plot served as an original creation of a cookie-cutter Hollywood. It was also nice that this movie retained a PG rating. Even though, some parents may want to be aware that there are about two scenes which may not be suitable for very young children. But for the most part, this movie is an excitement factory for all ages.

The lead actor, Jackie Chan, performs another timeless and ageless role handsomely. Along with the trademark martial arts, Jackie Chan's character, Jimmy Tong, was the funniest one I have ever seen him portray as his character offers plenty comedic moments. This role is different than the roles we have become accustomed to seeing Jackie Chan perform. Jimmy Tong was clumsy at times, brilliant at other times, as this reluctant hero becomes just so likable in a equally impressive tuxedo that turns him into a mix between Spiderman and James Bond. After watching this movie, it is no wonder why Jackie Chan is revered by many fans; only he could be suited for this tux.

The leading lady, the enchanting Jennifer Love Hewitt, takes on her complex character of Del Blaine with incredible talent and succeeded in delivering the array of the character's emotions and thoughts. Del Blaine would also be known to use her established beauty to manoeuvre through many tough times. This performance by this great actress proves how terrific an actress JLH is yet been seen for by many incomprehensive critics.

In the fight scenes, The traditional martial arts moves of Jackie Chan are present in every fight scene. But everyone else in the movie performed just as masterfully in these scene, especially JLH. As in all Jackie Chan movies, this motion picture provides a final action scene which will make you remember the Tuxedo. Some matrix-like wire acts are commissioned but overall, they end up enhancing the martial art skills.

In conclusion, great movie which I found far more entertaining than many movies this year.

To DreamWorks: Please make a sequel and remember that Toronto is open.

Jackie Chan is usually known for silly irreverent fun but perhaps this one goes too far in that direction. It doesn't live up to his other material with flat comedy and action. The story is also too typical and uninteresting.

If a movie stars Jackie Chan, then there's a 90% chance that it's going to be a series of wacky stunts with a silly plot attached. That's definitely the case with "The Tuxedo". The main difference here is that Chan's character isn't a guy who knows martial arts; instead, a fancy outfit gives him nearly limitless abilities.

As for Jennifer Love Hewitt, most of her scenes look like excuses to show off her body (she's definitely a babe here). Basically, it's the sort of movie that lets you shut your brain off for a few hours while the star does a bunch of zany stuff. I suspect that they had a lot of fun filming it. Certainly one that you'll enjoy.

review_title: Hollywood doesn't know what to do with the brilliant Jackie Chan
review_detailed_main:
You'd have thought Hollywood could have taken Jackie Chan's brilliant understanding of performance martial arts, action and comedic timing into terrific films. But it never seemed to get him and it shows in this film.

It's the pitifully weak central idea, ludicrous plot and weak dialogue that take a great cast of actors (Jennifer Love Hewitt, Jason Isaacs, Peter Stormare) and wastes them in idiotic plotlines. JLH's characters is put through a series of tired old knob-joke style lines that show the writers had run out of ideas. Which is a tragedy with all the skills they had on offer and the cast can't be blamed for that, apart from for signing up maybe. They should have just run instead of taking the money first.

Jackie Chan seems to get pushed into the second support role, presumably because Hollywood doesn't think he's leading man material. They just don't seem to know what to put him in there.

review_title: Formulaic Jackie Chan movie lives up to previous films.
review_detailed_main: Predictable, contrived, hokey, yet THE TUXEDO entertains. Jackie Chan delivers another easy-to-go mix of action, lovely women and laughs that will attract filmgoers of all ages. Jennifer Love Hewitt is a good foil (funny, smart and sexy) for the amiable Chan. Without giving away too much of the plot, the tuxedo transports our Ordinary Joe Chan into a wild adventure (something to do with corrupt water). A surprise cameo by James Brown is a plus. Take the family. Take a date. Or rent the DVD.

This was like watching two movies .. One with Jackie Chan - witty, interesting storyline (although a little predictable and shaky in places) and the other with Jackie and Jennifer Love Hewitt - so bad it was painful. The director must have said to her "make your character as whingy and nonsensical as possible" because she nailed that portrayal down perfectly.

The movie had moments of that ole Jackie Chan brillance. I think they tried to make Hewitt's character into the female equivalent of his successful teamings with Owen Wilson - needless to say they should keep on lookin! If he had had a better co-star (e.g Debi Mazar - shes got quite a witty sarcasm which she can carry off) to work with, I think the movie would have been received better.

So if your a Jackie fan ... probably not for you, if your a Love Hewitt fan, probably your cup of tea!!

Sure I've seen better films with Chan but I still liked it. It's not much of surprises and a simple plot but worth seeing a Friday night. Chan still has that sense of humor no other martial arts actor can match.

A super tuxedo, would't you like to wear one? You will after seeing this one! When his new boss is wounded in a attack he gives John(Chan) the assignment to finish a mission and wear his special tuxedo. Gave me bit of a Dr Gadget feeling. See it, its worth it.

Jimmy Tank is the simple driver of the famous millionaire Clark Devlin. Due to an accident, Clark is hospitalized and Jimmy, who is sent to bring some of his things to his house, accidentally wears Clark's suit and realizes that he has strange powers and... Tuxedo movie (The Tuxedo) is a 2002 action, comedy and science fiction film directed by Kevin Donovan. In this movie, Jackie Chan, Jennifer Love Hewitt, Jason Isaacs, Debbie Mazar, Richie Caster, Peter Strummer, Romani Malko, Daniel Cash, Boyd Banks, Bob Balaban, Christian Potenza, James Brown, Scott Yaffe, Noah Danby, Colin McRae, Kim Roberts and others played. This film produced by Dreamworks Pictures won the best actor and the best actress and was also nominated for the best actor with Jackie Chan at the Kids' Choice Awards in America.

review_title: Dumb Movie Saved By Hewitt and Some Funny Lines
review_detailed_main: 28 September 2002. Sadly, this isn't Jackie Chan's best nor even good movie. The pacing and plot seems to fall apart about a fourth of the way into the movie becoming dumb and dumber. What audiences expect from Jackie Chan doesn't get full play here and the best part of the movie is Chan's famous closing credits. Hewitt gets some great lines and acting parts and saves the movie from becoming a complete waste. The movie had potential, the number of funny lines are numerous, and the effort laudable, but unfortunately, neither Hewitt nor Chan can save this movie. More of Devlin's presence, the superspy, would have been helpful in a movie such as this but Chan had to suffer having to somehow carry the whole load of the irony in this movie, better shared with another actor.

review_title: poor jackie chan, Jennifer Love Hewitt ruined this little movie
review_detailed_main:
4 out of 10 This movie had a good concept, an idea that could have worked. If it just wouldn't have been for the annoying I-am-a-sexy-woman-but-still-tough-and-funny Jennifer Love Hewitt. She ruined this little flick. The scenes with Jackie alone are all pretty funny. But as soon as Hewitt tries to be funny it all goes down the drain... What a pity!

Better go watch Rush Hour again!

Jimmy Tong (Jackie Chan) is a taxi driver who can't seem to ask his dreamgirl out. Steena (Debi Mazar) comes in and hires the fast driver to be the chauffeur for super wealthy Clark Devlin (Jason Isaacs). They become friendly but Jimmy doesn't know that Devlin is a superspy. A bombing puts Devlin in the hospital. Jimmy goes back to the mansion and puts on the tuxedo which turns out to be a high tech gear with extraordinary powers. Del Blaine (Jennifer Love Hewitt) is support at CSA headquarters who mistakenly assumes that Jimmy is Devlin as Jimmy goes on assignment against the villain Dietrich Banning (Ritchie Coaster) and his plan to take over the water supply.

Jackie Chan is not a good comedian in English. Some people make that mistake from his work in the Rush Hour movies. Essentially, he is the straight man in those movies. He still has difficulties doing non-physical comedic work in English. This just puts all that up front. The location work isn't the best trying to make the Toronto NYC transition. The story makes very limited logical sense. There was a chance that this movie could go full camp when Jackie Chan starts doing James Brown. However this is more sad than funny.

review_title: All I can say is that everyone at the moviehouse was laughing hard.
review_detailed_main: Not much of a story but seriously what do you expect from a Jackie Chan movie? At least they didn't focus too much on the already much-abused 'evil genius plotting a world-spanning scheme' theme and simply focused on what Jackie can do -- make a movie where he is the SPECIAL EFFECT. I had lots of laughs while watching this movie. The action isn't as nonstop as the Rush Hour movies but there is enough to go by. I wasn't disappointed, and by their reaction, so were the rest of the people who watched this one with me. I'm glad I didn't listen to the critics' reviews. :)

review_title: no chemistry between Jackie and Jennifer
review_detailed_main: After watching The Tuxedo on opening night, I could say I'm quite dissapointed. A movie headlined by Jackie Chan really needed something with chemistry and Jennifer Love Hewitt isn't it. This movie was definitly marketed for ten year olds rather than the usual Chan fan. I went to see it for Jackie Chan. Jennifer Love Hewitt looks great, but her acting career really took a back step. Maybe that new musical career should be permanent. Also, the main plot of the movie really isn't ever announced in the movie. You have to assume what the problem is. They never say what the problem is (I dont wanna give anything away). Some of the stunts with Chan are so fake, it doesn't seem like a Jackie Chan movie. Anyway, the movie needed more "realistic" fighting and original ideas, although the James Brown gig was quite funny. I also cant argue with the hilarious outtakes at the end of the movie, which is becoming standard with all Chan movies. In all, I wouldnt spend $10 bucks to watch this movie in theatres. If I were you, Id wait for it to come on DVD to rent.

review_title: A true waste of time and money
Spy film that doesn't take itself seriously...
review_detailed_main:
Okay - if you are familiar with Jackie Chan's Hollywood work at all, you'll have a pretty good idea what to expect here. Cheesy effects, hokey jokes, and high action are the Chan trademarks and they're all present and accounted for in this film.

I would say that if you're looking for a good popcorn film, or just some mindless entertainment to amuse yourself -- this is the show to see. Fun date film, and a great film for the teen set.

If you're looking for intrigue, thrills, whodunit or edge of your seat nailbiting - this ain't it. It's pure light fun that doesn't even bother with a plausible plot.

If you're looking for something like Rumble in the Bronx (Chan's best in my eyes - though I'm no expert) - this ain't it either.

However - it is a fun way to spend a day - and it's worthy of a rainy afternoon, especially in the midst of the dry season we seem to be having at the movies lately.

I give the flick a 6/10 for its sheer will to entertain us. It's not original, but it is fun. Besides - a shot of Hewitt's cleavage should thrill the teen set immensely.

review_title: The comedy makes up for the bad direction/editing.
review_detailed_main: The first thirty minutes with Jackie Chan and Jason Isaacs are good. Isaacs is great as the real Clark Devlin, even though he doesn't have much to do in the film. Jackie Chan is likable especially when he does his James Brown impression. Jennifer Love Hewitt is cute, but isn't able to garner up much of a performance. Due to the age difference they weren't able to explore a real relationship between the two. It's not a good movie, but it looks nice and Jackie Chan is funny. 4/10 Fair

Not a great film. The storyline is over the top and feels like a leftover Bond script from the 70s. Chan is likable as normal, but the film is flat and over the top. This could have been much better had they trimmed some of the staged humour. The cast is having fun, but they struggle with the filmmakers style over substance and poorly executed story beats. The Tuxedo may appeal to the younger crowd who enjoy quick humour. What was the deal with the first shot of the deer urinating in the creek? Who in their right mind would choose this as an opening shot.

review_title: Not one of Jackie Chan's best movies

review_detailed_main: Great Spy Spoof, Jackie Chan at his best and great stunts. If you want a serious film don't watch this, but if you want a laugh this is for you. Whole family loved it.

review_title: Great First 20 Minutes, Then Forget It !

review_detailed_main:
Jackie Chan is one of the greatest stars in cinema history, but since his move to Hollywood films his movies are going downhill.

And at the Bottom... The Tuxedo.

Jackie please, please don`t make any more like this.

When Miss Love-Hewitt is given more martial arts skill than JC (out of the tux) it shows that the makers have no idea about making a Jackie Chan film.

The stuntman standing in for Jackie is often obvious as well.

Oh I can`t be bothered going on - If you want to see Jackie at is best go rent/buy Police story or Project A.

review_title: Lack of plot, lack of Jackie

review_detailed_main:
I loved the beginning of The Tuxedo. Debi Mazar gets into the back of Jackie Chan's taxi and gives him a destination. If he can get her there before she finishes putting on her makeup, she'll double the fee. As he speeds, swerves, and takes dangerous short-cuts, she informs him on her progress. Since his performance is so satisfactory, she hires him to be a private chauffeur for her boss, Jason Isaacs.

Besides being a good driver, Jackie has no special skills in this movie. What a surprise, right? And what a short movie, since nothing interesting can happen. Just kidding - Jason Isaacs is a secret agent. When Jason winds up in a coma, Jackie (through some twists and turns) finds himself taking his place. But how can a chauffeur pass for a secret agent? Through a magical tuxedo. . .

Jackie is just adorable in this movie, and there are tons of laughs and sweet moments sprinkled in among the impressive action sequences. Where else will you get to see him disco dance and perform James Brown songs? He's just adorable as he masters a new skill: fooling the audience into thinking his clothes are doing all the work. As his legs and arms have a mind of their own, he mugs his hilarious expressions and goes along for the ride. Jennifer Love Hewitt plays Jackie's sidekick and pseudo-love interest. She's a scientist who's been looking forward to working with Jason Isaacs, so she's understandably confused when Jackie shows up in his place. She does get to wear some very pretty dresses, though. For one of Jackie's fluffiest roles, check him out wearing The Tuxedo.

Another Jackie Chan movie as usual.Fighting scenes are a bit the same like in al his movies,exept they get a twist of comedy with it now.Good movie and one to see. Good story and not just a kick and beat 'em up movie.

Greets El Loco

I found this film to be one of Jackie Chan's funniest films since the "Rush Hour" films! For the first time in Jackie Chan's film career, his unique fighting ability, that he displays so flawlessly, is attributed to a formal dining ensemble(the tuxedo)! Chan has also showed his uncanny ability to play well on screen opposite just about anyone who is paired with him regardless of race or gender as he does here with the very beautiful and talented Jennifer Love Hewitt! Be prepared for a non-stop romp of laughs as well as Chan's signature arsenal of stunts in this one! Chan and Hewitt deliver the kind of chemistry that might very well land them two a sequel to this film! The special effects come off dazzling and flawless! If you're a fan of Jackie Chan's, then you need to continue to support his efforts with your viewing of this film! You will not be disappointed, I promise you!

This Movie was fun to watch. Had action and comedy it kept me interested. I watched it with my wife and 8 year old son. Both enjoyed it and the sex content was low so nothing to explain to the 8 year old. I don't think I would watch the movie again and again but it was a good time.

I'm a little disappointed at the many negative reviews I've read for The Tuxedo on this site. I think they are a little unfair. The Tuxedo is a good, fun, James Bond-style spoof in the same mode as Austin Powers or Johnny English. Yet in many ways I think it is better than the competition: It's got some great action sequences, it moves along quickly and never seems dull, and there are lots of funny moments too.

Above all else, it is a great family movie and the certification here in the UK reflects that fact. Maybe many of the other reviewers seem to have forgotten who the movie is ultimately aimed at? Anyhow, my kids and I are looking forward to the DVD release and will definitely be adding it to our DVD collection!

review_title: The most mediocre movie I've ever seen

review_detailed_main: This is another great movie with Jackie Chan. I would have rather had Jimmy not use an advanced tuxedo to fight, but I still think that the movie is awesome. The action is great and my favorite scene is the fight scene at the end (like usual). I think that this is somewhere in my top five favorite Jackie Chan movies. The British C.S.A. agent was almost a fake, but he's still cool. I wonder if he always uses the tuxedo to fight crime. If so, that is really lame. There is a minor plot hole in this. When Jimmy first activates the tuxedo, it says that it will attack any moving object, but the suit goes around the room attacking objects that aren't moving.

review_title: Disappointing. Mr. Chan should stick to what he knows best.
Is this a sharp and well-suited film? Check out my review below to find out!
review_detailed_main: "The Tuxedo" (2002), for those who may not know, I've recently reviewed my top two favorite Jackie Chan movies. Most of you know which one I think is his best film, that would be: "Mr. Nice Guy" (1997) and my second favorite of his movies is "The Medallion" (2003). I figured it was only fair to review my third favorite of his films, "The Tuxedo". I remember when I first saw this movie, I enjoyed it a lot. Then, the more I watched it, I found myself liking it even better! It has a perfect story, perfect acting, beautiful sets/locations, perfect special effects, and also a perfect soundtrack to tie it all together. The plot is, a hapless cab driver named Jimmy Tong gets hired to be a chauffeur for the wealthy secret agent named Clark Devlin, who owns a gadget-laden tuxedo. After Clark Devlin gets injured, Jimmy is forced to take his place. He dons his tuxedo, which gives him special powers and abilities. His mission is to stop Banning Corporation from poisoning the water supply. I won't go into any extra details about the story, but I promise that you'll be invested and laughing all the way from beginning to end. Probably the most unique aspect behind the plot of this film, is that Jackie Chan's character does not know any martial arts. His character only gains the ability when he puts on the tuxedo. At first, I thought that Jackie Chan not fighting as his normal self would ruin the whole idea of his skills in real-life. But, to tell you the truth, I thought it was an interesting change of pace! Watching someone like Jackie Chan on the screen not knowing martial arts is absolutely hilarious. Plus, when he puts on the tuxedo, the jokes and humor are raised up to 11! Just like in "The Medallion", I have the same nitpick here. That's right, I wish that this movie was longer! It may be 98 minutes in length, but it goes by in the blink of an eye. As for the acting, it's top-notch from the whole entire cast. Of course, Jackie Chan steals the show as usual. His acting never disappoints, and his performance here is no different! The rest of the cast does a phenomenal job as well. Jennifer Love Hewitt is funny as Jimmy's partner and eventual love interest, Delilah "Del" Blaine. Ritchie Costner as the villainous Dietrich Banning is fantastic. Every cast member nails their respectable character. Their chemistry on the screen is impeccable and they all help bring the film to life. All of the sets/locations are fantastic and give the film a beautiful atmosphere. As far as the special effects go, they are perfect and still hold up today. There are a few that are a bit cheesy. But, they get the job done and just give the movie that extra bit of charm. Finally, the soundtrack composed by Christophe Beck and John Debney is incredible. Their film score sets the perfect tone for the movie, and then some. Both of them are great film score composers on their own. But, when you have them both working and collaborating together, magic is created. "The Tuxedo" is a brilliant achievement in the world of action-comedy/martial arts movies. I can watch this movie over and over and never get tired of it. I'm giving this film 5 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 10 out of 10 IMDB stars. If you haven't seen "The Tuxedo" yet, go see it today. Especially if you're a huge fan of Jackie Chan! I promise that you'll love it. If you don't go see it, watch out for Dietrich Banning, he might poison your water!

review_title: Jackie Chan? Why Why Why did you use CGI?
WoW one of BEST jackie Chan Movies!!!
review_detailed_main: Realy one of his best movies ,it is like every movie that he delivers with Action, Funny Type movies but this time whith Dreamwoke prodaction and a good director the movie is realy good and specialy for Jackie Chan Fans they will Love it !!! don't miss this one ,,

Accept this movie for what it is. A fun, light-hearted action/comedy. If your expecting anything more you could be disappointed. If not you'll enjoy the ride. Some laughs, good action, and a quick pace make this an enjoyable diversion. Enjoy.

review_title: Not your average Jackie Chan film, pretty bad.
First Chon Wang, now James Tong...
review_detailed_main:
Hmmmmmmm, only Jackie Chan can get inspiration for a fight or two out of a tuxedo - a piece of clothing. I love odd ideas.

Ok, get the plot out of the way, spying, hapless character, evil baddie, and some idea for world domination. Thats all there is to the story. Good, leaves more time for action.

This is one of Jackie`s better recent movies, pity about the wire fights. Jackie, you are better than that, leave phoney fighting to the likes of The Matrix, Crouching Director Hidden Plot, et al, and come back to the style that you`re best at stupid life threatening stunts and lightening fast fights.

This hour and a half (or so) of movie was more entertaining than most of last years efforts, i`m looking in your direction Minority Report!

You cant see this movie and lot enjoy it.... well you can, but you would have to have a swinging brick instead of a heart.

Roll on Shanghai Nights.

Is this an Oscar film? No. Artistic? No. Great script? Uh-uh.

Huge fun for young fans and old? Yes! I love Jackie Chan movies because Jackie Chan loves making movies, and his energy and vigor are clearly up on the screen. I think Jackie & Jennifer work better than Jackie & Chris (although I think Chris Tucker's one of the funniest actors ever) because Jackie and Jennifer have a similar energy and laidback style.

I also love the wonderful dynamics of action that Jackie is the master of. Great human being as well.

The James Bond guy is a great actor (Patriot) and I hope he works in American movies more often. Very cute movie! Something you can take your 10-year-old kid brother to without worrying. 8 out of 10.

review_title: No laughs, no thrills, no excitement, no point  an embarrassing mess of stupid plot, rubbish effects, rubbish fights, easily one of the worst Chan films I have seen
A silly, fun romp, nowhere near as bad as you've probably heard
One of the greatest jackie chan movies ever
Chan's movies have a reputation for being quick, funny, and full of great action sequences and this one continues that tradition.
I liked it when it was funny; Chan and Hewitt great together
Well tailored and packed with laughs.
bland Chan supported by a pretty face - again
6/10, not as bad as I thought it was going to be.
It's Almost as Good as It Could Be
Why do the young lady's eyes keep changing color?
more for kids interested in gadgets
Hollywood nails the first nail into the coffin that was the 'Jackie Chan' movie
Kinda reminds you of The Greatest American Hero.
I wish a had like that!
I finally broke down and saw it...
Pointless, but good , somewhat clean , fun !
Couldn't continue watching it... 20 minutes left
This Tuxedo is definitely a Rental
